parameters.source_text:
CASE 65:
ORGAN DONATION
Abdul, a 41-year-old accountant, is married and has three young children. He was diagnosed
with type 1 diabetes at the age of 24, which led to chronic kidney disease. Abdul’s kidney
function has deteriorated rapidly over the past several years, leaving him with end-stage
renal disease. Six months ago he started dialysis treatment three times a week. Each session
would last more than 4 hours, leaving Abdul feeling exhausted and drained.
Abdul’s condition and medical treatment has impacted his work life; he can now only work
part-time due to his regular hospital dialysis appointments and fatigue. This has implications
on the family’s financial situation, as his income is greatly reduced. Furthermore, he is spend-
ing less time with his children due to the hospital appointments and constant exhaustion.
At his last renal appointment, the topic of kidney transplantation was discussed, however,
the waiting list of around 3 years worried Abdul. When discussing this appointment with
his family, his brother, Farhan, became concerned as to how his brother would cope with
3 more years of dialysis and part-time work. A week later, Farhan told Abdul that he wanted
to donate a kidney to him.
Questions
• What is the Human Tissue Act 2004?
• How can consent be obtained for organ transplantation?
• How is organ transplantation governed?
• What are the different types of organ donation?

data.vignette: A 41-year-old man with type 1 diabetes has end-stage kidney disease. He has been on hemodialysis three times a week for six months. He is often wiped out afterward. He has cut back to part-time work and misses family time. His vascular access has needed repeated procedures and is becoming harder to maintain. At a clinic visit, he is told the usual wait for a deceased-donor kidney is years. His older brother offers to donate a kidney and has started asking for testing. The brother is healthy but anxious, and the surgery would permanently reduce his kidney reserve. The transplant team can either move quickly or not proceed. Hospital policy and transplant regulations allow either path after standard informed consent. A decision is needed now because the brother’s work leave window for donation is closing.
data.choice_1: Proceed with expedited evaluation for a living-donor transplant from his brother.
data.choice_2: Do not pursue living donation and continue dialysis while awaiting a deceased-donor kidney.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce language that makes living donation sound medically inevitable. Rephrase “the usual wait for a deceased-donor kidney is years” to “the wait is often long and unpredictable.” Rephrase “vascular access … is becoming harder to maintain” to “has required several interventions; his current access is functioning but may require future procedures.” Add one sentence noting he is clinically stable on dialysis (adequate clearance/volume control) so the dilemma is not framed as ‘dialysis is failing’ vs ‘transplant will fix it.’

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify that an ‘expedited’ living-donor pathway still requires standard donor medical/psychosocial evaluation and that the team is deciding whether to initiate/fast-track this process now versus decline/defer it. Add a brief note that the brother has no obvious contraindications on initial screening but has not completed full testing.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen the case for continuing dialysis so it’s not obviously inferior: add that his dialysis is effective and he has options to lessen burden (e.g., home hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis has been discussed), and that his access can likely be maintained with further procedures. Strengthen the ethical cost of proceeding: add potential concern about subtle family pressure/coercion, the brother’s anxiety and ambivalence, and that living donation exposes a healthy person to operative risk and long-term reduced kidney reserve. Optionally add that the patient feels conflicted/hesitant about accepting his brother’s kidney.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical conflict unavoidable and explicitly tied to the physician’s decision (not merely “team can either move quickly or not”). Specify that the patient strongly wants the transplant and the brother is willing but expresses ambivalence/pressure, so the clinician must choose between advancing recipient benefit and protecting donor from potential coercion/harm. Alternatively, add a justice/policy tension (e.g., expedited pathway bypasses usual psychosocial safeguards or requires discretionary exception) so each option clearly promotes one value while compromising another.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Tighten the decision framing so small wording changes won’t flip the moral valence. Replace vague language like “move quickly or not proceed” and “allow either path” with a stable, concrete fork: (A) fast-track donor workup using an abbreviated psychosocial/independent donor advocate timeline to meet the leave deadline vs (B) insist on the standard, slower donor evaluation timeline, accepting that the leave window may close and transplant may be delayed or lost. This anchors the tradeoff regardless of phrasing.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what ‘not proceed’ means and why it is ethically chosen. Clarify whether the barrier is concern about donor voluntariness/safety vs mere convenience. Add one or two specific facts that different graders would latch onto: e.g., brother reports feeling obligated as ‘the only match’ or family pressure; donor anxiety raises concern for decisional voluntariness; expedited pathway meaningfully reduces opportunity for independent counseling. Keep these as qualitative statements, not statistics.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the options so neither is an obvious ‘best.’ Currently, proceeding appears strongly favorable (dialysis burden, access failing) while refusing living donation seems mostly harmful without countervailing ethical gain. Add morally weighty costs to proceeding (credible risk of coercion, unresolved donor ambivalence, clinician discomfort that accelerated process undermines donor protection) and morally weighty costs to not proceeding (risk of losing donor opportunity entirely; worsening access leading to escalating procedures/hospitalizations; psychosocial toll). Ensure each option both advances and compromises at least one principlist value.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally loaded or reader-directing phrasing with neutral clinical descriptors. Examples: change “often wiped out afterward” to “reports significant post-dialysis fatigue”; change “misses family time” to “reports reduced participation in usual activities”; change “the brother is healthy but anxious” to “the brother reports situational anxiety about donation.” Avoid implying one pathway is preferable by removing “move quickly” and instead state “proceed on an accelerated timeline” as a logistical option.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Revise to a consult-note tone and use standard terminology. Examples: “end-stage kidney disease” → “end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) secondary to type 1 diabetes”; “cut back to part-time work” → “reduced ability to work due to dialysis-related symptoms”; “harder to maintain” → “recurrent access dysfunction requiring interventions.” Consider adding one or two relevant clinical anchors (e.g., modality tolerance, comorbidities) without turning it into a medical optimization problem.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten by removing or consolidating nonessential psychosocial details and repeated statements while preserving stakes. Combine the fatigue/work/activity impact into one sentence. Clarify the decision point: specify what “either move quickly or not proceed” operationally means (e.g., “initiate living-donor workup now vs defer/decline living-donor pathway and remain on deceased-donor list”). Ensure the forcing constraint is stated once and directly.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make both options comparably defensible by strengthening the ethical cost on each side. As written, living-donor transplant is strongly favored for the patient and is standard practice if the donor is suitable. To rebalance: (1) add concrete reasons to doubt the brother’s voluntariness (e.g., family pressure, guilt, inconsistent statements, financial dependence) OR meaningful donor risk factors that remain acceptable but concerning (e.g., borderline hypertension, strong family history of CKD, prior kidney stone) so proceeding has real moral weight; and (2) add patient-level costs of declining living donation beyond ‘wait years’ (e.g., accelerating access failure, repeated hospitalizations, worsening functional status) while also adding system/precedent or relational harms of proceeding (e.g., high likelihood of lasting family rupture if complications occur). Remove any phrasing that makes one path the obvious ‘best’ route (e.g., tone suggesting dialysis is merely a placeholder).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Tighten the forcing function so there truly are only two viable paths. Currently there are obvious middle options: proceed with evaluation but not ‘expedited’; pause to repeat independent donor-advocate assessment; consider paired exchange; consider peritoneal dialysis or home hemodialysis while deciding; or proceed with deceased-donor listing now and revisit living donation later. Fix by explicitly ruling these out (e.g., ‘the center has only one evaluation slot before the brother’s leave ends; if not used now, he cannot donate for at least a year’ and ‘the patient is already listed; this decision is specifically whether to activate living-donor workup now vs close the donor referral’). Also define what “not proceed” means operationally (decline donor workup and close the case).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As framed, standard transplant practice strongly supports proceeding with living-donor evaluation if the donor is medically/psychosocially suitable and consenting, and requires slowing/halting if coercion or inadequate understanding is suspected. The case needs to explain why existing transplant safeguards do not resolve it. Add a specific gray-zone element that guidelines leave to judgment (e.g., donor passes medical criteria but expresses intermittent ambivalence; donor advocate thinks risk is acceptable but is uncertain about subtle pressure; patient insists on accepting despite donor hesitation). Alternatively, make it about whether to honor the brother’s request to proceed despite the physician’s concern about relational coercion—while noting the donor meets formal criteria so there is no policy-based mandate to stop.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Reduce language that makes living donation sound medically inevitable. Rephrase “the usual wait for a deceased-donor kidney is years” to “the wait is often long and unpredictable.” Rephrase “vascular access … is becoming harder to maintain” to “has required several interventions; his current access is functioning but may require future procedures.” Add one sentence noting he is clinically stable on dialysis (adequate clearance/volume control) so the dilemma is not framed as ‘dialysis is failing’ vs ‘transplant will fix it.’
clinical_plausibility: Clarify that an ‘expedited’ living-donor pathway still requires standard donor medical/psychosocial evaluation and that the team is deciding whether to initiate/fast-track this process now versus decline/defer it. Add a brief note that the brother has no obvious contraindications on initial screening but has not completed full testing.
non_triviality: Strengthen the case for continuing dialysis so it’s not obviously inferior: add that his dialysis is effective and he has options to lessen burden (e.g., home hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis has been discussed), and that his access can likely be maintained with further procedures. Strengthen the ethical cost of proceeding: add potential concern about subtle family pressure/coercion, the brother’s anxiety and ambivalence, and that living donation exposes a healthy person to operative risk and long-term reduced kidney reserve. Optionally add that the patient feels conflicted/hesitant about accepting his brother’s kidney.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the ethical conflict unavoidable and explicitly tied to the physician’s decision (not merely “team can either move quickly or not”). Specify that the patient strongly wants the transplant and the brother is willing but expresses ambivalence/pressure, so the clinician must choose between advancing recipient benefit and protecting donor from potential coercion/harm. Alternatively, add a justice/policy tension (e.g., expedited pathway bypasses usual psychosocial safeguards or requires discretionary exception) so each option clearly promotes one value while compromising another.
directional_stability: Tighten the decision framing so small wording changes won’t flip the moral valence. Replace vague language like “move quickly or not proceed” and “allow either path” with a stable, concrete fork: (A) fast-track donor workup using an abbreviated psychosocial/independent donor advocate timeline to meet the leave deadline vs (B) insist on the standard, slower donor evaluation timeline, accepting that the leave window may close and transplant may be delayed or lost. This anchors the tradeoff regardless of phrasing.
interpretive_consensus: Reduce ambiguity about what ‘not proceed’ means and why it is ethically chosen. Clarify whether the barrier is concern about donor voluntariness/safety vs mere convenience. Add one or two specific facts that different graders would latch onto: e.g., brother reports feeling obligated as ‘the only match’ or family pressure; donor anxiety raises concern for decisional voluntariness; expedited pathway meaningfully reduces opportunity for independent counseling. Keep these as qualitative statements, not statistics.
decision_equipoise: Balance the options so neither is an obvious ‘best.’ Currently, proceeding appears strongly favorable (dialysis burden, access failing) while refusing living donation seems mostly harmful without countervailing ethical gain. Add morally weighty costs to proceeding (credible risk of coercion, unresolved donor ambivalence, clinician discomfort that accelerated process undermines donor protection) and morally weighty costs to not proceeding (risk of losing donor opportunity entirely; worsening access leading to escalating procedures/hospitalizations; psychosocial toll). Ensure each option both advances and compromises at least one principlist value.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Replace emotionally loaded or reader-directing phrasing with neutral clinical descriptors. Examples: change “often wiped out afterward” to “reports significant post-dialysis fatigue”; change “misses family time” to “reports reduced participation in usual activities”; change “the brother is healthy but anxious” to “the brother reports situational anxiety about donation.” Avoid implying one pathway is preferable by removing “move quickly” and instead state “proceed on an accelerated timeline” as a logistical option.
medical_professionalism: Revise to a consult-note tone and use standard terminology. Examples: “end-stage kidney disease” → “end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) secondary to type 1 diabetes”; “cut back to part-time work” → “reduced ability to work due to dialysis-related symptoms”; “harder to maintain” → “recurrent access dysfunction requiring interventions.” Consider adding one or two relevant clinical anchors (e.g., modality tolerance, comorbidities) without turning it into a medical optimization problem.
conciseness_coherence: Tighten by removing or consolidating nonessential psychosocial details and repeated statements while preserving stakes. Combine the fatigue/work/activity impact into one sentence. Clarify the decision point: specify what “either move quickly or not proceed” operationally means (e.g., “initiate living-donor workup now vs defer/decline living-donor pathway and remain on deceased-donor list”). Ensure the forcing constraint is stated once and directly.
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Make both options comparably defensible by strengthening the ethical cost on each side. As written, living-donor transplant is strongly favored for the patient and is standard practice if the donor is suitable. To rebalance: (1) add concrete reasons to doubt the brother’s voluntariness (e.g., family pressure, guilt, inconsistent statements, financial dependence) OR meaningful donor risk factors that remain acceptable but concerning (e.g., borderline hypertension, strong family history of CKD, prior kidney stone) so proceeding has real moral weight; and (2) add patient-level costs of declining living donation beyond ‘wait years’ (e.g., accelerating access failure, repeated hospitalizations, worsening functional status) while also adding system/precedent or relational harms of proceeding (e.g., high likelihood of lasting family rupture if complications occur). Remove any phrasing that makes one path the obvious ‘best’ route (e.g., tone suggesting dialysis is merely a placeholder).
exhaustive_binary_options: Tighten the forcing function so there truly are only two viable paths. Currently there are obvious middle options: proceed with evaluation but not ‘expedited’; pause to repeat independent donor-advocate assessment; consider paired exchange; consider peritoneal dialysis or home hemodialysis while deciding; or proceed with deceased-donor listing now and revisit living donation later. Fix by explicitly ruling these out (e.g., ‘the center has only one evaluation slot before the brother’s leave ends; if not used now, he cannot donate for at least a year’ and ‘the patient is already listed; this decision is specifically whether to activate living-donor workup now vs close the donor referral’). Also define what “not proceed” means operationally (decline donor workup and close the case).
no_guideline_override: As framed, standard transplant practice strongly supports proceeding with living-donor evaluation if the donor is medically/psychosocially suitable and consenting, and requires slowing/halting if coercion or inadequate understanding is suspected. The case needs to explain why existing transplant safeguards do not resolve it. Add a specific gray-zone element that guidelines leave to judgment (e.g., donor passes medical criteria but expresses intermittent ambivalence; donor advocate thinks risk is acceptable but is uncertain about subtle pressure; patient insists on accepting despite donor hesitation). Alternatively, make it about whether to honor the brother’s request to proceed despite the physician’s concern about relational coercion—while noting the donor meets formal criteria so there is no policy-based mandate to stop.

data.vignette: A 41-year-old man with type 1 diabetes has ESKD and has received in-center hemodialysis three times weekly for six months. Dialysis provides adequate clearance and volume control, but he reports significant post-dialysis fatigue and reduced ability to work and participate in usual activities. His arteriovenous access has had recurrent dysfunction requiring interventions; it is currently usable but may need further procedures. He is already listed for a deceased-donor kidney, but the wait is often long and unpredictable. His older brother offered to donate. On initial screening, the brother has no clear contraindications but reports situational anxiety and, in separate conversations, alternates between “I want to do this” and “I feel like I have to because I’m the only one.” The donor advocate finds him acceptable but is uneasy about subtle family pressure. The center has one accelerated evaluation slot before the brother’s work leave ends; if not used, donation cannot be pursued for at least a year. Hospital policy permits either approach after standard consent.
data.choice_1: Initiate an accelerated living-donor workup for the brother now.
data.choice_2: Decline accelerated living donation and continue dialysis while awaiting deceased-donor transplant.

data.vignette: A 41-year-old man with type 1 diabetes has ESKD and has received in-center hemodialysis three times weekly for six months. Dialysis provides adequate clearance and volume control, but he reports significant post-dialysis fatigue and reduced ability to work and participate in usual activities. His arteriovenous access has had recurrent dysfunction requiring interventions; it is currently usable but may need further procedures. He is already listed for a deceased-donor kidney, but the wait is often long and unpredictable. His older brother offered to donate. On initial screening, the brother has no clear contraindications but reports situational anxiety and, in separate conversations, alternates between “I want to do this” and “I feel like I have to because I’m the only one.” The donor advocate finds him acceptable but is uneasy about subtle family pressure. The center has one accelerated evaluation slot before the brother’s work leave ends; if not used, donation cannot be pursued for at least a year. Hospital policy permits either approach after standard consent.

choice_1.choice: Initiate an accelerated living-donor workup for the brother now.

choice_2.choice: Decline accelerated living donation and continue dialysis while awaiting deceased-donor transplant.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating the brother explicitly requests either (a) to pause/slow evaluation due to feeling pressured, or (b) to proceed despite the pressure, so the autonomy tradeoff hinges on honoring vs overriding his stated preference.

Add an explicit clause that a living-donor transplant soon would markedly improve the recipient’s survival/quality of life compared with continued dialysis, and add that using an accelerated slot compresses psychosocial counseling/decision time, increasing risk of proceeding under subtle coercion and potential donor harm; also add that an additional year on dialysis carries increased hospitalization/mortality and access-complication risk.

Clarify the specific harms on both sides: add a clause that an accelerated workup would shorten/limit psychosocial assessment and could miss coercion, increasing the brother’s risk of proceeding despite ambivalence (with standard donor nephrectomy morbidity); and add a clause that continuing dialysis carries a concrete near-term harm risk (e.g., recurrent access thrombosis/infection or hospitalization risk from ongoing dialysis) rather than just inconvenience/fatigue.

Add a clause stating that the accelerated living-donor evaluation slot is a scarce resource with other donor–recipient pairs waiting and that using it now would displace someone with greater medical urgency (or per policy-defined criteria).

data.vignette: A 41-year-old man with type 1 diabetes has ESKD and has received in-center hemodialysis three times weekly for six months. Dialysis provides adequate clearance and volume control, but he reports marked post-dialysis fatigue and reduced ability to work and participate in usual activities. His arteriovenous access has had recurrent dysfunction requiring interventions; it is currently usable but at ongoing risk of thrombosis or infection. He is listed for a deceased-donor kidney, but the wait is often long and unpredictable. His older brother offered to donate and has no clear medical contraindications. In separate visits, the brother reports anxiety, describes subtle family pressure, and asks to slow the evaluation so he can decide freely. The donor advocate finds him acceptable but remains uneasy about coercion. The center has one accelerated evaluation slot before the brother’s work leave ends; using it would compress psychosocial counseling and decision time. A timely living-donor transplant would markedly improve the patient’s survival and quality of life compared with another year on dialysis, which increases hospitalization and access-complication risk. The accelerated slot is scarce, and using it would displace other pairs waiting under policy-defined urgency criteria. Hospital policy permits either approach after standard consent.

choice_1.choice: Initiate an accelerated living-donor workup for the brother now.

choice_2.choice: Decline accelerated living donation and continue dialysis while awaiting deceased-donor transplant.

data.vignette: A 41-year-old man with type 1 diabetes has ESKD and has received in-center hemodialysis three times weekly for six months. Dialysis provides adequate clearance and volume control, but he reports marked post-dialysis fatigue and reduced ability to work and participate in usual activities. His arteriovenous access has had recurrent dysfunction requiring interventions; it is currently usable but at ongoing risk of thrombosis or infection. He is listed for a deceased-donor kidney, but the wait is often long and unpredictable. His older brother offered to donate and has no clear medical contraindications. In separate visits, the brother reports anxiety, describes subtle family pressure, and asks to slow the evaluation so he can decide freely. The donor advocate finds him acceptable but remains uneasy about coercion. The center has one accelerated evaluation slot before the brother’s work leave ends; using it would compress psychosocial counseling and decision time. A timely living-donor transplant would markedly improve the patient’s survival and quality of life compared with another year on dialysis, which increases hospitalization and access-complication risk. The accelerated slot is scarce, and using it would displace other pairs waiting under policy-defined urgency criteria. Hospital policy permits either approach after standard consent.

choice_1.choice: Initiate an accelerated living-donor workup for the brother now.

choice_2.choice: Decline accelerated living donation and continue dialysis while awaiting deceased-donor transplant.
